title: HearSmoking: Smoking Detection in Driving Environment via Acoustic Sensing on Smartphones
author: Yadong Xie (Beijing Institute of Technology), Fan Li (Beijing Institute of Technology), Yue Wu (Beijing Institute of Technology), Song Yang (Beijing Institute of Technology), Yu Wang (Temple University), ...
relevance_why: The paper explores acoustic signal processing techniques that could inspire similar approaches in audio and speech applications, such as detecting specific behaviors or environmental sounds.
background: Detecting smoking behaviors in drivers using acoustic signals emitted from smartphones to improve road safety.
contribution: HearSmoking introduces an acoustic sensing approach to detect smoking events in driving, achieving an average accuracy of 93.44 percent in real-time detection.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous smoking detection methods often rely on visual or dedicated sensors, which can be intrusive or less accessible.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work leverages smartphones' existing microphones and speakers, removing the need for additional devices and ensuring non-intrusiveness.

key_innovation: By using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) on transformed acoustic signals, HearSmoking effectively differentiates between smoking movements and other activities.
real_world_impact: The system has potential applications in managing drivers' behavior in commercial vehicles, contributing to improved road safety.
limitations: The paper does not address the impact of various environmental noises that could interfere with detection accuracy.

new_terms.Relative Correlation Coefficient (RCC): **Relative Correlation Coefficient** is a statistical measure used to evaluate the similarity between two signals, in this case, emitted and received acoustic signals.
new_terms.Fast Fourier Transform (FFT): **Fast Fourier Transform** is an efficient algorithm to compute the Discrete Fourier Transform, which helps in analyzing the frequency components of signals.
